entry.title: Journal: Week 27
entry.content:
Highlights of the Week

another hectic week, but honestly, one of the most productive ones ina while! i really felt like i was in the zoneâ€”managed to squeeze in alot of things and complete everything i had planned. â˜ºï¸

aside from work, i finally set aside a night to discuss our upcomingphuket trip in march with vinoth & yousheng! it's always exciting tohave something to look forward to.

also! i gave my bro a comprehensive leg day breakdown!

he's currently in spain for his degree, so we had to do it over avideo call, which was a completely different experience compared to myprevious sharing session with toby, where we did it in person.explaining movements virtually made me realise how important it is to beconcise and clearâ€”i had to be extra mindful of my words to ensure myexplanations made sense without demonstrating in real time. i found thischallenge really interesting and, surprisingly, quite enjoyable!

being a personal trainer has always been something i'm passionateabout. not because i want to make it a career, but because i lovesharing my knowledge and experience with othersâ€”helping them avoid thesame mistakes i made, guiding them towards better progress, and seeingthem grow in their own journey. witnessing someone improve because ofsomething i taught them? that's one of the best feelings ever. ğŸ¥¹

it also reinforces my own understanding of fitness. as Steve Bartlettmentioned in his book, if you want to truly master something, you needto be able to teach it to others. i can really see the truth in thatnow.

it also deepens my own understanding of fitness. as Steven Bartlettmentioned in his book, if you want to truly master something, you needto be able to teach it to others. this concept has always been in me,but experiencing it firsthand through coaching hits differentlyâ€”it's areminder that teaching doesn't just help others grow, "when one personis teaching, two people learn", it solidifies my own knowledge too.

Reading Insights

this week, i revisited chapter 5 of Never Split theDifferenceâ€”"Triggering the Two Words That Immediately Transform AnyNegotiation." i've been actively trying to apply the paraphrasing +labeling technique to summarise conversations better. the idea is to notjust restate what was said but also acknowledge the emotions behinditâ€”this makes the other person feel truly heard.

it's definitely not an easy skill to master, but i can see myselfimproving. learning how to communicate effectively has been one of mybiggest goals this year, and this small tweak in how i summariseconversations is already making a difference.

Memories

17 ~ 23 feb

also! i gave my bro a comprehensive leg day breakdown!

he's currently in spain for his degree, so we had to do it over a video call, which was a completely different experience compared to my previous sharing session with toby, where we did it in person. explaining movements virtually made me realise how important it is to be concise and clearâ€”i had to be extra mindful of my words to ensure my explanations made sense without demonstrating in real time. i found this challenge really interesting and, surprisingly, quite enjoyable!

being a personal trainer has always been something i'm passionate about. not because i want to make it a career, but because i love sharing my knowledge and experience with othersâ€”helping them avoid the same mistakes i made, guiding them towards better progress, and seeing them grow in their own journey. witnessing someone improve because of something i taught them? that's one of the best feelings ever. ğŸ¥¹

it also reinforces my own understanding of fitness. as Steve Bartlett mentioned in his book, if you want to truly master something, you need to be able to teach it to others. i can really see the truth in that now.

it also deepens my own understanding of fitness. as Steven Bartlett mentioned in his book, if you want to truly master something, you need to be able to teach it to others. this concept has always been in me, but experiencing it firsthand through coaching hits differentlyâ€”it's a reminder that teaching doesn't just help others grow, "when one person is teaching, two people learn", it solidifies my own knowledge too.

this week, i revisited chapter 5 of Never Split the Differenceâ€”"Triggering the Two Words That Immediately Transform Any Negotiation." i've been actively trying to apply the paraphrasing + labeling technique to summarise conversations better. the idea is to not just restate what was said but also acknowledge the emotions behind itâ€”this makes the other person feel truly heard.

it's definitely not an easy skill to master, but i can see myself improving. learning how to communicate effectively has been one of my biggest goals this year, and this small tweak in how i summarise conversations is already making a difference.

entry.title: Go Notebook
entry.content:
ğŸš€ Intro

i'm diving into Go to add a new tool to my coding arsenal, aiming toharness its speed and efficiency for those times when JavaScript justcan't keep up with massive datasets. By tackling LeetCode problems andcomparing solutions with JS, i'm not just learning a new languageâ€”i'mpreparing for real-world scenarios where Go's lightweight nature andconcurrency shine. Whether it's crunching big data or optimisingperformance, having Go as an option means i'm ready for whatever codingchallenges come my way. ğŸš€

CriteriaGo ğŸ¦«JavaScript ğŸŸ¨
Speed5-10x faster for CPU tasksSlower, but adequate for most web apps
Memory Efficiency~1/3 JS usage, manual controlAutomatic, hits ~4GB limit
Best For- Big data (>1GB)
- High concurrency
- CLI tools		- Web APIs
- UI apps
- Prototyping
ConcurrencyGoroutines (cheap, 1MB each)Worker threads (heavy, ~10MB)
EcosystemGrowing stdlib, fewer libsMassive NPM ecosystem
Learning CurveStrict types, explicit error handlingFamiliar syntax, flexible types
When to UseData pipelines, microservicesFull-stack apps, quick scripts

Data Pipeline = A series of automated steps that collect, process,and move data from one system to another (e.g., CSV files â†’ cleaned dataâ†’ database).

Decision Checklist:

  1. Processing >1GB data? â†’ Go
  2. Need precise memory control? â†’ Go > Precise Memory Control = InGo, you manually manage memory allocation (e.g., buffer := make([]byte,0, 1024) pre-allocates 1KB), preventing unexpected memory spikes commonin JS.
  3. Building UI/API? â†’ JS
  4. Team knows JS better? â†’ JS
  5. Need single binary? â†’ Go (A self-contained executable with alldependencies packed in)

ğŸ“Œ Core Concepts

ConceptJavaScript ExampleGo Example & Notes
Variableslet x = 10;x := 10 (type inferred)
var y int = 20(explicit)
Constantsconst PI = 3.14;const PI = 3.14(untyped)
const (A=1; B=2) (grouped)
Functionsfunction add(a, b) { ... }func add(a int, b int) int { ... }
Multiple returns:(int, error)
Data TypesDynamic typingStatictyping:
var s string = "text"
n := 3.14(float64)
Collectionsconst arr = [1,2];
const obj = {key:1};		arr := []int{1,2}(slice)
m := map[string]int{"key":1}
type S struct{Key int}
Zero Valuesundefined, null0, "", false,nil (explicit defaults)
Error Handlingtry/catchif err != nil { ... }
val, err := someFunc()
ConcurrencyPromise, async/awaitgo func() { ... }(goroutines)
ch := make(chan int)
MemoryAutomatic GCManual control:
buf := make([]byte, 0, 1024)(pre-alloc)
Buildnode script.jsgo build â†’ single binary
No external runtimeneeded

Code Examples

Common Questions

  1. What is := in Go? â†’ Short variable declaration (createsand assigns value at once).
  2. Can you use let in Go? â†’ No, use var or:= instead.
  3. Can you reassign a variable in Go? â†’ Yes, but you can't redeclarethe same variable name.
  4. Can := be used to reassign new value to a variable? â†’Yes, but you can't redeclare the same variable name.
  5. Do I need to specify types in Go? â†’ No, but Go is statically typed.Use var x int = 10 or x := 10.
  6. What is hoisting? â†’ In JavaScript, var declarations aremoved to the top of the scope before code execution. Go does not havehoisting, so variables must be declared before use.
  7. What is * in Go? â†’ It is a pointer. It is used to storethe address of a variable.
    1. When should I use it? â†’ When you want to pass a variable byreference. (Need more explanation)

âš™ï¸ Functions

FeatureJavaScriptGo
Basic Functionfunction add(a, b) { ... }func add(a int, b int) int { ... }
Return ValuesSingle valueMultiple values: return val, err
Anonymous Func() => {}func() { ... }
Closure Supportâœ…âœ…

Code Examples

Common Questions

  1. Can functions return multiple values? â†’ Yes,return val1, val2.
  2. How do I handle optional parameters? â†’ Use variadic functions:func sum(nums ...int) int.
  3. Can we pass an object-like structure to a function like JS? â†’ Usestructs in Go.

ğŸ›  Data Structures

Arrays/Slices vs JS Arrays

OperationJavaScriptGo
Createconst arr = [1,2,3];slice := []int{1,2,3}
Appendarr.push(4)slice = append(slice, 4)
Lengtharr.lengthlen(slice)
CapacityDynamiccap(slice)

Code Examples

Key Differences

AspectJavaScriptGo
Memory ManagementAutomaticManual control
Array Growthpush() handles everythingappend() may need reallocations
PerformanceOptimised for convenienceOptimised for control
Best PracticeJust use push()Pre-allocate when size is known

(WIP) PracticalExample: Collecting 1M Numbers

JavaScript (Automatic)
Go (Manual Control)

When to Pre-allocate in Go

  1. Known Size - When you know the maximumelements
  2. Performance Critical - High-frequencyoperations
  3. Large Data - Processing big datasets
  4. Memory Efficiency - Constrained environments

When Not to Pre-allocate

  1. Small Data - Few elements, minimal impact
  2. Unknown Size - Can't predict capacity
  3. Prototyping - Focus on functionality first

Real-world Pattern

Key Takeaways

  1. JavaScript - Just use push(), enginehandles memory
  2. Go - Pre-allocate with make() whenperformance matters
  3. Trade-off - Go gives control, JavaScript offerssimplicity
  4. Best Practice - In Go, pre-allocate for knownsizes, otherwise let append handle it

Common Questions

  1. What is the difference between arrays and slices? â†’ Arrays havefixed sizes; slices are dynamic.
  2. How do I initialize an empty slice? â†’ var arr []int orarr := make([]int, 0).

Objects vs Structs

FeatureJavaScriptGo
Definitionconst obj = { ... };type Struct struct { ... }
Methodsobj.method = () => {}func (s Struct) Method() {}
ImmutabilityObject.freeze()Unexported fields

Code Examples

JS Maps vs Go Maps

FeatureJavaScriptGo
Create a Mapconst myMap = new Map();myMap := make(map[int]int)
Set a ValuemyMap.set(1, 'a');myMap[1] = "a"
Get a ValuemyMap.get(1)val := myMap[1]
Check ExistencemyMap.has(1)val, exists := myMap[1]

Common Questions

  1. How do I check if a key exists in Go? â†’val, exists := myMap[key] (returns value & boolean in_, _ format).
  2. Does Go have an equivalent of JavaScript objects? â†’ Use structsinstead of maps for structured data.

ğŸš¨ Error Handling (WIP)

PatternJavaScriptGo
Basic Handlingtry { ... } catch(err) {}if err != nil { return err }
Error Creationthrow new Error("error ...")return errors.New("error ...")
Custom Errorsclass CustomErrortype CustomError struct{...}

Code Examples

Common Questions

  1. Does Go have exceptions? â†’ No, Go uses if err != nil.
    • How to handle errors like a pro? Is there a cleaner way to handleerrors?
  2. How do I create a custom error? â†’errors.New("message").

ğŸ”„ Concurrency Patterns (WIP)

ConceptJavaScriptGo
Async Operationasync/awaitGoroutines
CommunicationPromisesChannels
ParallelismWorker ThreadsGoroutines + CPU Cores

Code Examples

ğŸ† Best Practices (WIP)

ğŸ“š Python vs Go: Choosingthe Right Tool

CriteriaPython ğŸGo ğŸ¦«
Code Readabilityâœ… Super concise, easy to readâŒ More verbose (need structs, types)
Library Supportâœ… Tons of built-in functions (heapq, collections, bisect)âŒ Need to manually implement data structures like heaps, sets
Typingâœ… Dynamic (faster coding)âŒ Static (safer but more rigid)
Execution SpeedâŒ Slower for large inputs (interpreted)âœ… Faster (compiled, better memory efficiency)
Memory UsageâŒ Higher (Garbage Collected, dynamic objects)âœ… Lower (Manual memory control, efficient types)
ConcurrencyâŒ Python's GIL limits true parallel executionâœ… Go routines are lightweight and great for concurrency
Industry Use in SWEâœ… Used in ML, Web Dev, and Scripting (most interviews supportPython)âœ… Used in backend, cloud, and infra (great for system-heavyroles)
LeetCode Community & Discussionâœ… More Python solutions, easier to find helpâŒ Fewer Go solutions, harder to debug

ğŸš€ LeetCode Roadmap for Go

Phase 1: Learning GoBasics (1-2 Weeks)

Goal: Get comfortable with Go syntax and basic concepts.

  • âœ… Variables, Constants, and Types (:=,var, const)
  • âœ… Functions (func, multiple return values)
  • âœ… Data Structures (map, slice,struct)
  • âœ… Pointers (*, &)
  • âœ… Loops (for, range)
  • âœ… Error Handling (if err != nil)

Phase 2: EasyLeetCode Questions (2-3 Weeks)

Goal: Manage to solve easy questions in Go without much help.

  • âœ… Arrays & Strings
  • âœ… HashMaps & Sets
  • âœ… Linked Lists

Phase 3: MediumLeetCode Questions (3-5 Weeks)

Goal: Manage to solve medium questions in Go without much help.

  • âœ… Sorting & Searching
  • âœ… Recursion & Backtracking
  • âœ… Graphs & Trees

Phase 4: Hard LeetCodeQuestions (Ongoing)

Goal: Manage to solve hard questions in Go without much help.

  • âœ… Graphs & Trees

Phase 5: Advanced Go Concepts

Goal: Get comfortable with advanced Go concepts.

  • âœ… Goroutines & Concurrency
  • âœ… Channels & Select Statements
  • âœ… Writing Go Unit Tests (testing package)

ğŸ§© LeetCode Practices

35. SearchInsert Position

Key Insight

Binary search implementation where left pointernaturally converges to insertion point when target not found.

Go Implementation

Go-Specific Learnings

  1. Loop Structure for left <= rightreplaces JS while loop
  2. Mid Calculation left + (right-left)/2prevents integer overflow
  3. Return Value left always points toinsertion index post-loop

Edge Cases

  • Empty array â†’ returns 0
  • Target smaller than all elements â†’ 0
  • Target larger than all elements â†’ len(nums)

Complexity

  • Time: \(O(log n)\)
  • Space: \(O(1)\)

Why This Works

  • Binary search reduces problem space by half each iteration
  • Final left position reflects where target wouldmaintain sorted order

118. Pascal'sTriangle

Key Insight

Pre-allocate slices and manually initialize endpoints since Go arrayslack built-in fill methods.

Go Implementation

Go-Specific Learnings

  1. Slice Initialisation
    • make([]int, n) creates zero-initialised slices
    • Must manually set first/last elements to 1
  2. Nested Slices make([][]int, rows) â†’Each inner slice needs separate allocation
  3. Index Boundaries j runs from1 to i-1 to avoid overwriting endpoints

Memory Management

ApproachGoJavaScript
Creationmake([]int, 0, capacity)new Array(n).fill(0)
FillManual initialisationBuilt-in fill() method
MatrixNested make() callsArray of arrays

Example for make([]int, 0, capacity):

Edge Cases

  • numRows = 0 â†’ Return empty slice
  • numRows = 1 â†’ [[1]]

Complexity

  • Time: \(O(nÂ²)\) - Each elementcomputed once
  • Space: \(O(nÂ²)\) - Stores entiretriangle

Why This Works

  • Pre-allocation avoids slice growth overhead
  • Mathematical properties of Pascal's Triangle enable efficientcomputation

2364.Count Number of Bad Pairs

Key Insight

Transform j - i != nums[j] - nums[i] â†’i - nums[i] != j - nums[j]. Track i - nums[i]counts using map.

Go Implementation

Go-Specific Learnings

  1. Map Initialisationcache := make(map[int]int)

    • Zero-value initialised (no nil issues)
    • Auto-expands as needed

  2. Unused Variables Go compiler errors if:

  3. Efficient Counting

    • cache[key] returns 0 if missing (no panic)
    • cache[key]++ handles insertion/update

Complexity

  • Time: \(O(n)\) - Single pass withmap lookups
  • Space: \(O(n)\) - Worst-case uniquekeys

Why This Works

  • Each key collision represents a good pair
  • Total pairs = \(n * (n-1)/2\)
  • Bad pairs = Total - Good

219.Contains Duplicate II

Key Insight

Track last seen indices using a hashmap to check for duplicateswithin k distance in \(O(n)\) time.

Go Implementation

Go-Specific Learnings

  1. Map Initialisationmake(map[int]int) creates an empty hashmap thatauto-expands

  2. Index Management

    • Store current index on each iteration
    • Check i-j (not absolute value sincei > j)

  3. Efficiency

    • Single pass \(O(n)\) time
    • Worst-case \(O(n)\) space for allunique elements

Edge Cases

  • k=0 â†’ Always false (indices must differ)
  • All elements unique â†’ false
  • Duplicates exactly k apart â†’ true

Complexity

  • Time: \(O(n)\)
  • Space: \(O(n)\)

228. SummaryRanges

Key Insight

Track range starts and detect gaps in a single pass, leveraging Go'sslice efficiency for \(O(n)\) time.

Go Implementation

Go-Specific Learnings

  1. Slice Management

    • Pre-allocate with var ranges []string
    • Use append for dynamic growth

  2. Helper Functions Extract formatting logic forcleaner code

  3. Edge Cases

    • Empty input â†’ return empty slice
    • Single element â†’ ["5"]

Complexity

  • Time: \(O(n)\) - Single passthrough array
  • Space: \(O(n)\) - Worst case storesn/2 ranges

Why This Works

  • Detects non-consecutive numbers(nums[i] != nums[i-1]+1)
  • Builds ranges incrementally
  • Handles final range outside loop

ğŸš§ WIP ...

entry.title: Journal: Week 24
entry.content:
Highlights of the Week

as i mentioned in my last journal, i went back to JB on saturday forCNY, and honestly, last week was just so much fun! finally got to spendsome quality time with my fam and relatives, catching up properly,talking more, and getting to know a little bit more about everyone. ğŸ¥° idid so much better this timeâ€”heehee!

CNY definitely feels a little less exciting as i grow older ğŸ¥º, butno matter what, i still love the vibes. the food, the red packets, themahjong (YES, i finally learnt how to play this year! but honestly... itain't my thing heehee), the gambling (without money for me!), thelaughter, the jokes, the stories, the memoriesâ€”every little moment thatmakes CNY feel like home. ğŸ§§ even if the excitement fades a little withage, i realise it's never really about the traditions themselves, butthe people we share them with.

but deep down, watching everyone get older and the kids grow up hitsdifferently now. there's this bittersweet feelingâ€”like i wish i couldfreeze time, just for a little while, and relive those moments again,exactly as they were. but i guess that's just life, right? we grow up,time moves forward, and all we can do is cherish what we have while westill have it. ğŸ¥²

çœŸçš„ï¼Œæ—¶é—´å•Šï¼Œ

ä½ æ€ä¹ˆä¸åœ¨è¯¥æ…¢çš„æ—¶å€™æ…¢ä¸€äº›...

ä½ å¯ä»¥åœ¨æˆ‘çˆ±çš„äººèº«ä¸Šæµå¤±å¾—æ…¢ä¸€äº›ä¹ˆ

but even with these emotions lingering, there were so many beautifulmoments to hold onto. lo hey, fireworks, endless rounds of catching up,and just chilling at home with familyâ€”those were easily the best partsof the week. no matter how old i get, these are the moments i'll alwaystreasure. ğŸ†ğŸ§¨

of course, there were some small conflicts here and there, but that'sjust part of family dynamics. misunderstandings, miscommunicationsâ€”ithappens. but at the end of the day, what matters is that we learn, wegrow, and we appreciate each other more. ğŸ¤ after all, without the lows,how would we ever truly appreciate the highs?

entry.title: Journal: Week 23
entry.content:
Highlights of the Week

what a productive week at work! ğŸ¥°

i finally released the feature that i conducted UAT for last year inbeijing, and honestly, what an indescribable feeling of seeing it golive without a critical bug? OK TOUCH WOOD... ğŸ˜³ it's momentslike these that remind me why i love what i doâ€”everything justfeels worth it. very good progress overall, and i couldn't be happier!ğŸ¥°ğŸ’ªğŸ¼

another win this week was making strides in improving mycommunication skills. i've been focusing on active listening and givingothers the space to share their thoughts, and it's been so rewarding. ialso had a lovely lunch with a colleague from another team at parisbaguetteâ€”my virgin try! the food was really nice, and the company madeit even better.

on the fitness front, i managed to push myself to a real to-failureleg day on friday. but guys, did it hit hard... the soreness was real bysaturday, just in time for my trip to JB for chinese new yearcelebrations. ğŸ¥² and, of course, life had a little twist waiting formeâ€”while walking after tapping out of the mrt, i got the worst cramp inmy right calf muscle. it was so painful i had to stop walking and leanagainst the wall with my eyes closed, trying to recover.

as i stood there, i sensed someone looking at me. when i opened myeyes, i saw this guy staring at me, his expression full of concern. heraised his hand, clearly wanting to help. i shook my head and gave himan "OK" ğŸ‘ŒğŸ¼ sign, reassuring him i was fine. even as he walked away, hekept turning back to check on me. it's these little acts of kindnessthat restore your faith in humanity and leave a lasting impression. thatstranger? he made my day, and i'll always remember his kindness. ğŸ¥¹

it reminded me that even the smallest acts can mean so much tosomeone, so i'll be sure to double it, and pass it on to the next personwhenever i can. ğŸŒŸ

Reading Insights

i have been revisiting the book Never Split the Differenceby Christopher Voss, making notes on the key takeaways and strategiesthat resonate with me. you may check it out here.

when you visit, it might still be a work in progress draft, but i'mworking on it! ğŸ“

Memories

entry.title: Journal: Week 22
entry.content:
Highlights of the Week

i haven't been so busy for quite a while, damn, it was such aproductive week! a few nights, i stayed up alone in the office, pouringin some extra effort just to complete things. one of the biggestaccomplishments was finishing my self-review for 2024. writing downreflections on each project i worked on really made me pause and thinkdeeply.

while writing my self-review on key outputs, i realised how much i'veparticipated in, but at the same time, i can't help but feel like icould have done more. it wasn't about slacking off, but how some tasksseemed almost too easy compared to my past experiences. don't get mewrong thoughâ€”what i mean by "easy" is that it was less challenging interms of technical knowledge.

thinking back to project H (let's keep it hashed forconfidentiality), i remember how overwhelming it was at the start. therequirements were straightforward when i look at them now, but backthen? oh boy, it was another story entirely. the business chinesejargon? it felt like my brain hit a complete blank.

as someone raised in malaysia, speaking chinese, switching to malayin secondary school, and then studying in singapore for three yearsbefore settling here for over seven... let's just say my language systemgot a serious workout. juggling those languages while trying to graspthe project requirements? yeah, it was intense. i felt so out of mydepth.

when i look back at it now, (yes, i'm smiling ğŸ¥¹), jinghui, youâ€™vecome so far. you did so well! even those late nights staying up until4am, panicking about whether you'd make the deadline... you still madeit. all the mistakes you made during each project? they're the reasonyou are where you are today.

that realisation hit me deeply this week. it's moments like thesethat remind me of why i push myselfâ€”to grow, to overcome, and to keepbuilding my confidence.

Memories

my note: after keeping my photos here i will be deleting most of themon my phone teeheee
entry.summary:
Highlights of the Week

i haven't been so busy for quite a while, damn, it was such a productive week! a few nights, i stayed up alone in the office, pouring in some extra effort just to complete things. one of the biggest accomplishments was finishing my self-review for 2024. writing down reflections on each project i worked on really made me pause and think deeply.

while writing my self-review on key outputs, i realised how much i've participated in, but at the same time, i can't help but feel like i could have done more. it wasn't about slacking off, but how some tasks seemed almost too easy compared to my past experiences. don't get me wrong thoughâ€”what i mean by "easy" is that it was less challenging in terms of technical knowledge.

thinking back to project H (let's keep it hashed for confidentiality), i remember how overwhelming it was at the start. the requirements were straightforward when i look at them now, but back then? oh boy, it was another story entirely. the business chinese jargon? it felt like my brain hit a complete blank.

as someone raised in malaysia, speaking chinese, switching to malay in secondary school, and then studying in singapore for three years before settling here for over seven... let's just say my language system got a serious workout. juggling those languages while trying to grasp the project requirements? yeah, it was intense. i felt so out of my depth.

when i look back at it now, (yes, i'm smiling ğŸ¥¹), jinghui, youâ€™ve come so far. you did so well! even those late nights staying up until 4am, panicking about whether you'd make the deadline... you still made it. all the mistakes you made during each project? they're the reason you are where you are today.

that realisation hit me deeply this week. it's moments like these that remind me of why i push myselfâ€”to grow, to overcome, and to keep building my confidence.

entry.title: Journal: Week 21
entry.content:
Highlights of the Week

this week i made a conscious effort to be more productive at work-notjust to compensate for the time spent on my beijing trip, but also tochallenge myself. i wanted to prove that with the right mindset, i couldpush my limits and achieve so much more. it's all about mentalresilience. at work, i've been handling a requirement with manageablecomplexity, but it demands a critical focus on detail. as part of mygoal this year, i'm striving to do things well, notjust get them done. it's about adopting the mindset of Done vs DoneWell, and this task is no exception. i've been taking my time,ensuring that the quality of my work aligns with that principle. it'sbeen challenging, but i'm enjoying the process of learning and growingin this area. ğŸ¯

as for the weekend, it was nothing short of amazing! i had the chanceto gather with my relatives for an earlier Lo Hey (æé±¼ç”Ÿ) @ TungLok Peking Duck Novena! it feltso good to reconnect with them after such a long time, and it was agreat way to kick off the lunar new year celebrations! ğŸ§§ on top ofthat, it happened to be my aunty's birthday (è‚¥è‚¥å¦ˆå¦ˆ). i surprised herwith a cake, and the restaraunt went extra mile-they presented the cakeon a large plate with dry ice underneath, creating an amazing fogeffect. to top it off, they played some chinese EDM birthday songs,adding to the festive vibe HAHA! loved it so much, it was such a fun andheartwarming moment. big up to åŒä¹ for making the celebration sospecial!

Reading Insights

as i have been kind of like relearning from the book of Never Split theDifferences by Chris Voss, i have been trying to revise and applysome of the negotiation tactics in my daily life. it's been quiteinteresting to see how these strategies can be used in varioussituations, not just in business or high-stakes scenarios. i'm stillworking on mastering the art of tactical empathy and calibrated "no,"but i'm excited to see how these skills evolve over time. ğŸ“š

i have been utilising these methods in my conversations withcolleagues and friends, and it's been fascinating to observe the subtleshifts in dynamics and outcomes. i'm also trying to be more mindful ofmy body language and tone of voice, as these non-verbal cues play asignificant role in communication. it's a work in progress, but i'menjoying the process of learning and growing in this area. ğŸ’¬

SO! i was randomly cleaning up my Spotify's playlist and saw that ihave been following The Diary Of A CEO with Steven Bartlett podcast!which i planned to listen but always forgot to... so i clicked on it andsaw a topic just caught my eye! Body LanguageExpert: Stop Using This, Itâ€™s Making People Dislike You, So Are TheseSubtle Mistakes! and i was like, "ok, that sounds interesting!" so iclicked on it and started listening to it. it was quite an insightfulepisode, and i learned a lot about the importance of body language incommunication, she called it the language of cues. i've always beenfascinated by the power of non-verbal cues, and this podcast episodereinforced the idea that our body language can speak volumes about ourthoughts and emotions. it's a reminder to be more aware of how i presentmyself in different situations and how i can use body language toenhance my communication skills at work and in my personal life!

  • The Diary Of A CEOLinks - Vanessa Van Edwards

Memories

Highlights of the Week

this week i made a conscious effort to be more productive at work-not just to compensate for the time spent on my beijing trip, but also to challenge myself. i wanted to prove that with the right mindset, i could push my limits and achieve so much more. it's all about mental resilience. at work, i've been handling a requirement with manageable complexity, but it demands a critical focus on detail. as part of my goal this year, i'm striving to do things well, not just get them done. it's about adopting the mindset of Done vs Done Well, and this task is no exception. i've been taking my time, ensuring that the quality of my work aligns with that principle. it's been challenging, but i'm enjoying the process of learning and growing in this area. ğŸ¯

as for the weekend, it was nothing short of amazing! i had the chance to gather with my relatives for an earlier Lo Hey (æé±¼ç”Ÿ) @ TungLok Peking Duck Novena! it felt so good to reconnect with them after such a long time, and it was a great way to kick off the lunar new year celebrations! ğŸ§§ on top of that, it happened to be my aunty's birthday (è‚¥è‚¥å¦ˆå¦ˆ). i surprised her with a cake, and the restaraunt went extra mile-they presented the cake on a large plate with dry ice underneath, creating an amazing fog effect. to top it off, they played some chinese EDM birthday songs, adding to the festive vibe HAHA! loved it so much, it was such a fun and heartwarming moment. big up to åŒä¹ for making the celebration so special!

Reading Insights

as i have been kind of like relearning from the book of Never Split the Differences by Chris Voss, i have been trying to revise and apply some of the negotiation tactics in my daily life. it's been quite interesting to see how these strategies can be used in various situations, not just in business or high-stakes scenarios. i'm still working on mastering the art of tactical empathy and calibrated "no," but i'm excited to see how these skills evolve over time. ğŸ“š

i have been utilising these methods in my conversations with colleagues and friends, and it's been fascinating to observe the subtle shifts in dynamics and outcomes. i'm also trying to be more mindful of my body language and tone of voice, as these non-verbal cues play a significant role in communication. it's a work in progress, but i'm enjoying the process of learning and growing in this area. ğŸ’¬

SO! i was randomly cleaning up my Spotify's playlist and saw that i have been following The Diary Of A CEO with Steven Bartlett podcast! which i planned to listen but always forgot to... so i clicked on it and saw a topic just caught my eye! Body Language Expert: Stop Using This, Itâ€™s Making People Dislike You, So Are These Subtle Mistakes! and i was like, "ok, that sounds interesting!" so i clicked on it and started listening to it. it was quite an insightful episode, and i learned a lot about the importance of body language in communication, she called it the language of cues. i've always been fascinated by the power of non-verbal cues, and this podcast episode reinforced the idea that our body language can speak volumes about our thoughts and emotions. it's a reminder to be more aware of how i present myself in different situations and how i can use body language to enhance my communication skills at work and in my personal life!

  • The Diary Of A CEO Links - Vanessa Van Edwards

the first part of the week was packed with practices and preparationfor the countdown performance. since i had just returned from my beijingtrip, i was a bit behind on the crew's routines and didn't get a chanceto practise with them earlier. it felt like i had to play catch-up, so iput in extra effort to get back on track. despite the challenges, wepulled it off, and the performance went really well. the fireworks werelovely, and the energy of the crowd was incredible. being part of theteam and performing on stage was such a rewarding experience, and wereally really did so well! so proud of us! ğŸ‰

even after the performance, i managed to squeeze in some gymtimeâ€”because dedication doesn't take a break! the rest of the week wasabout catching up on sleep and easing back into my usual routine of workand gym.

i also started a loading phase of ~20g of creatine per day for 7days, beginning on 3rd january 2025. on top of that, i tried a newprotein shake flavour (surprisingly good) and treated myself to alate-night mcd's supperâ€”it's all about balance, right? ğŸ™Š

overall, it was a short but fulfilling week, blending beatboxing,fitness, and a bit of relaxation. can't wait to see what the next weekbrings!

entry.title: Never Split The Difference by Chris Voss
entry.content:
"Never Split the Difference" is a book by Chris Voss, a former FBIhostage negotiator, that offers negotiation advice you can use in dailylife. The book is centered around the idea that traditional negotiationstrategies, like "splitting the difference," are often ineffective. Vossprovides a range of psychological strategies and tactics to use innegotiations, derived from his experience in dealing with criminals,terrorists, and other high-stakes situations.

Life is negotiation.

Key concepts from the book include:

  1. Mirroring: Mimicking the other person's languageand behavior to build rapport.
  2. Labeling: Verbally acknowledging the other person'ssituation, feelings, or viewpoints.
  3. The "Accusation Audit": Preemptively addressing allof the other party's potential accusations and concerns.
  4. Tactical Empathy: Understanding the feelings andmindset of another in the moment and also hearing what is behind thosefeelings so you increase your influence in all the moments thatfollow.
  5. The "Calibrated 'No'": Saying "No" in a way thatinvites more discussion, as opposed to shutting it down.
  6. Bargaining Strategies: Like setting an "AnchorPrice" or using odd numbers to make a price seem more exact.
  7. The "Black Swan" Rule: The idea that there areunknown, unpredictable elements in every negotiation that can be used toyour advantage.

Chapter 1: The New Rules

The majority of the interactions we have at work and at home arenegotiations that boil down to the expression of a simple, animalisticurge: I want.

â€œI want you to free the hostages,â€ is a very relevant one to thisbook, of course.

But so is:

â€œI want you to accept that $1 million contract.â€

â€œI want to pay $20,000 for that car.â€

â€œI want you to give me a 10 percent raise.â€ and

â€œI want you to go to sleep at 9 p.m.â€

Negotiation serves two distinct, vital life functionsâ€”informationgathering and behaviour influencingâ€”and includes almost any interactionwhere each party wants something from the other side.

â€œI was employing what had become one of the FBIâ€™s most potentnegotiating tools: the open-ended question. Today, after some yearsevolving these tactics for the private sector in my consultancy, TheBlack Swan Group, we call this tactic calibrated questions: queries thatthe other side can respond to but that have no fixed answers. It buysyou time. It gives your counterpart the illusion of controlâ€”they arethe one with the answers and power after allâ€”and it does all thatwithout giving them any idea of how constrained they are by it.â€

Psychotherapy research shows that when individuals feel listenedto, they tend to listen to themselves more carefully and to openlyevaluate and clarify their own thoughts and feelings. In addition,they tend to become less defensive and oppositional and more willing tolisten to other points of view, which gets them to the calm and logicalplace where they can be good Getting to Yes problem solvers.

Getting what you want out of life is all about getting what you wantfromâ€”and withâ€”other people. Conflict between two parties is inevitablein all relationships. So itâ€™s usefulâ€”crucial, evenâ€”to know how to engagein that conflict to get what you want without inflicting damage.

â€œThe first step to achieving a mastery of daily negotiation is to getover your aversion to negotiating. You donâ€™t need to like it; you justneed to understand thatâ€™s how the world works. Negotiating does notmean browbeating or grinding someone down. It simply means playing theemotional game that human society is set up for. In this world, you getwhat you ask for; you just have to ask correctly. So claim yourprerogative to ask for what you think is right.

What this book is really about, then, is getting you to acceptnegotiation and in doing so learn how to get what you want in apsychologically aware way. Youâ€™ll learn to use your emotions, instincts,and insights in any encounter to connect better with others, influencethem, and achieve more.

Effective negotiation is applied people smarts, a psychological edgein every domain of life: how to size someone up, how to influence theirsizing up of you, and how to use that knowledge to get what youwant.â€

Chapter 2: Be A Mirror

Assumption blinds,hypothesis guide

Good negotiators, going in, know they have to be ready for possiblesurprises; great negotiators aim to use their skills to reveal thesurprises they are certain exist.

In negotiation, each new psychological insight or additional piece ofinformation revealed heralds a step forward and allows one to discardone hypothesis in favor of another. You should engage the process with amindset of discovery. Your goal at the outset is to extract and observeas much information as possible. Which, by the way, is one of thereasons that really smart people often have trouble beingnegotiatorsâ€”theyâ€™re so smart they think they donâ€™t have anything todiscover.

â€œuntil you know what youâ€™re dealing with, you donâ€™t know what youâ€™redealing with.â€

Calm the Schizophrenic

Schizophrenia: everyone just listening to the voice in theirhead.

â€œto avoid this, we need to apply true active listening which willdisarm the other party and make them feel heard, safe andunderstood.â€œ

â€œSmile at someone on the street, and as a reflex theyâ€™ll smile back.Understanding that reflex and putting it into practice is critical tothe success of just about every negotiating skill there is tolearn.â€

Mirroring

Mirroring, also called isopraxism, is essentially imitation.Itâ€™s another neurobehavior humans (and other animals) display in whichwe copy each other to comfort each other. It can be done with speechpatterns, body language, vocabulary, tempo, and tone of voice. Itâ€™sgenerally an unconscious behaviorâ€”we are rarely aware of it when itâ€™shappeningâ€”but itâ€™s a sign that people are bonding, in sync, andestablishing the kind of rapport that leads to trust.

Itâ€™s a phenomenon (and now technique) that follows a very basic butprofound biological principle: We fear whatâ€™s different and are drawnto whatâ€™s similar.â€

â€œmirrorâ€ is when you repeat the last three words (or the criticalone to three words) of what someone has just said. Of the entiretyof the FBIâ€™s hostage negotiation skill set, mirroring is the closest onegets to a Jedi mind trick. Simple, and yet uncannily effective.

By repeating back what people say, you trigger this mirroringinstinct and your counterpart will inevitably elaborate on what wasjust said and sustain the process of connecting. PsychologistRichard Wiseman created a study using waiters to identify what was themore effective method of creating a connection with strangers: mirroringor positive reinforcement.â€

and usually they will not repeat the same thing again, but willelaborate on it. This is the key to getting more information from theother party.

How toConfront-And Get Your Way-Without Confrontation

  1. Use the late-night FM DJ voice.
  2. Start with â€œIâ€™m sorry . . .â€
  3. Mirror.
  4. Silence. At least four seconds, to let the mirror work its magic onyour counterpart.
  5. Repeat.

Key lessons

  • A good negotiator prepares, going in, to be ready for possiblesurprises; a great negotiator aims to use her skills to reveal thesurprises she is certain to find.
  • Donâ€™t commit to assumptions; instead, view them as hypotheses anduse the negotiation to test them rigorously.
  • People who view negotiation as a battle of arguments becomeoverwhelmed by the voices in their head. Negotiation is not an act ofbattle; itâ€™s a process of discovery. The goal is to uncover as muchinformation as possible.
  • To quiet the voices in your head, make your sole andall-encompassing focus the other person and what they have to say.
  • Slow. It. Down. Going too fast is one of the mistakes allnegotiators are prone to making. If weâ€™re too much in a hurry, peoplecan feel as if theyâ€™re not being heard. You risk undermining the rapportand trust youâ€™ve built.
  • Put a smile on your face. When people are in a positive frame ofmind, they think more quickly, and are more likely to collaborate andproblem-solve (instead of fight and resist). Positivity creates mentalagility in both you and your counterpart.
  • Mirrors work magic. Repeat the last three words (or the critical oneto three words) of what someone has just said. We fear whatâ€™s differentand are drawn to whatâ€™s similar. Mirroring is the art of insinuatingsimilarity, which facilitates bonding. Use mirrors to encourage theother side to empathize and bond with you, keep people talking, buy yourside time to regroup, and encourage your counterparts to reveal theirstrategy.

Three Voice TonesAvailable to Negotiators

  1. The late-night FM DJ voice: Use selectively to makea point. Inflect your voice downward, keeping it calm and slow. Whendone properly, you create an aura of authority and trustworthinesswithout triggering defensiveness.
  2. The positive/playful voice: Should be your defaultvoice. Itâ€™s the voice of an easygoing, good-natured person. Yourattitude is light and encouraging. The key here is to relax and smilewhile youâ€™re talking.
  3. The direct or assertive voice: Used rarely. Willcause problems and create pushback.

Chapter 3: Don't FeelTheir Pain, Label It

â€œHow can you separate people from the problem when their emotions arethe problem?â€

Tactical Empathy

Empathy is the ability to recognise the perspective of a counterpart,and the vocalisation of that recognition

Tactical empathy is understanding the feelings and mindset ofanother in the moment and also hearing what is behind those feelingsso you increase your influence in all the moments that follow.

Empathy is a classic â€œsoftâ€ communication skill, but it has aphysical basis. When we closely observe a personâ€™s face, gestures, andtone of voice, our brain begins to align with theirs in a process calledneural resonance, and that lets us know more fully what they think andfeel.

Empathy is not about being nice or agreeing with the other side. Itâ€™sabout understanding them. Empathy helps us learn the position the enemyis in, why their actions make sense (to them), and what might movethem.

Labelling

Labeling is a way of validating someoneâ€™s emotion by acknowledgingit. Give someoneâ€™s emotion a name and you show you identify with howthat person feels. It gets you close to someone without asking aboutexternal factors you know nothing about (â€œHowâ€™s your family?â€). Think oflabeling as a shortcut to intimacy, a time-saving emotional hack.

â€œLabeling has a special advantage when your counterpart is tense.Exposing negative thoughts to daylightâ€”â€œIt looks like you donâ€™t want togo back to jailâ€â€”makes them seem less frightening.

In one brain imaging study,2 psychology professor Matthew Liebermanof the University of California, Los Angeles, found that when people areshown photos of faces expressing strong emotion, the brain shows greateractivity in the amygdala, the part that generates fear. But when theyare asked to label the emotion, the activity moves to the areas thatgovern rational thinking. In other words, labeling an emotionâ€”applyingrational words to a fearâ€”disrupts its raw intensity.â€

Label methods:

  1. It seems like...
  2. It sounds like...
  3. It looks like...

The last rule of labeling is silence. Once youâ€™ve thrown out alabel, be quiet and listen. We all have a tendency to expand on whatweâ€™ve said, to finish, â€œIt seems like you like the way that shirtlooks,â€ with a specific question like â€œWhere did you get it?â€ But alabelâ€™s power is that it invites the other person to revealhimself.â€

WIP ...

Credits

All quotes are excerpted from "Never Split the Difference:Negotiating as if Your Life Depended on It by Chris Voss". This materialmay be protected by copyright.
entry.summary: "Never Split the Difference" is a book by Chris Voss, a former FBI hostage negotiator, that offers negotiation advice you can use in dail

entry.title: Resolution 2025: GPT's Brutally Honest Advice
entry.content:
the question i asked:

ChatGPT 4o

Here are some tailored resolutions for the new year, based on yourprofile and goals. They aim to address growth opportunities, refine yourstrengths, and challenge your limitations:

  1. Sharpen Focus on Long-Term Career Goals

    â€¢ Why? You have a strong technical foundation andleadership experience, but you're still seeking alignment between yourcurrent work and the broader industry.

    â€¢ Action: Set a clear 5-year plan and evaluate eachproject for its relevance to your ultimate goals (e.g., transitioning toa dream company like Google or excelling in high-impact roles likeProduction Engineer). Prioritise skills and projects that bring youcloser to these goals.

  2. Build Depth in Key Technologies

    â€¢ Why? Your expertise spans a wide array of toolsand platforms, but depth in fewer cutting-edge technologies (e.g.,Elixir or advanced DevOps practices) can set you apart.

    â€¢ Action: Commit to mastering one high-demandtechnology. Build a side project that demonstrates your expertise, withthe goal of open-sourcing it or presenting it at a techconference.

  3. Elevate Your Personal Brand

    â€¢ Why? Your personal website and online presence arestrong, but refining them with the modern polish and interactivity youaim for can elevate your visibility.

    â€¢ Action: Finish the v4 of your website, ensuring itreflects your skills dynamically (e.g., interactive portfolios, engagingvisuals, and a story-driven â€œAbout Meâ€). Incorporate beatboxing toshowcase your unique personality alongside professionalachievements.

  4. Prioritise Consistency Over Intensity

    â€¢ Why? Your projects often reflect deep effort butsuffer from scope creep and delayed timelines. This pattern could affectperception of reliability in team or stakeholder settings.

    â€¢ Action: Break big goals into manageable,measurable chunks. Use tools like OKRs to stay consistent and realisticabout deliverables. Document progress clearly to manageexpectations.

  5. Embrace Vulnerability and Human Connection

    â€¢ Why? Your focus on professionalism sometimesovershadows the emotional authenticity that builds deeper relationships.This may affect personal and professional connections.

    â€¢ Action: Let go of perfectionism in relationships(both personal and professional). Share your challenges, seek genuinefeedback, and make room for imperfections in others as well.

  6. Balance Hectic with Holistic

    â€¢ Why? Your gym schedule and work ethic arecommendable but seem to leave little room for reflection and emotionalrecharge.

    â€¢ Action: Integrate mindfulness or journaling intoyour routine. Dedicate one day a month to complete disconnectionâ€”nocoding, no emails, no gym. Use it for rest, reading, or exploringsomething entirely new.

  7. Date with Clarity and Confidence

    â€¢ Why? Your reflections on past dates show emotionaldepth but a tendency to overanalyse.

    â€¢ Action: Approach dating as an opportunity to learnand enjoy, not as a test. Set clear boundaries and communicate yourintentions upfront. Trust your instincts to know when someone isn't theright fit.

  8. Invest in Financial Literacy

    â€¢ Why? You've shown interest in investments likefractional stocks, but expanding financial acumen could offer long-termstability and freedom.

    â€¢ Action: Dive deeper into investment strategies.Consider automating contributions to ETFs like VOO, learning aboutREITs, or exploring small-scale entrepreneurial ventures like owning anAnytime Fitness gym.

  9. Advocate for Yourself and Your Team

    â€¢ Why? You're often focused on solutions andprojects, but advocating for your team's or your own success couldposition you as a stronger leader.

    â€¢ Action: Practice self-promotion withouthesitation. Document team wins and challenges, and share them openlywith stakeholders to highlight value and leadership.

  10. Let Go of â€˜What Ifs'

    â€¢ Why? Reflections on relationships, misseddeadlines, or professional missteps sometimes hold you back.

    â€¢ Action: Embrace a growth mindset. Celebrate thelessons from failures without overanalysing what could have been.Channel this into actionable steps for the future.

Would you like me to help break down any of these resolutions intospecific actions?

ChatGPT 1o

Below are several suggestions for your New Year's resolutions,tailored to what I understand are your aspirations and experiences. Ihave endeavoured to be frank yet constructive, and I hope these ideaswill provide a solid foundation for the year ahead.

  1. Pursue Further Education with Purpose

You have mentioned an interest in obtaining a part-time degree. Bebrutally honest with yourself about which area of study will bestcomplement both your technical and managerial career path. If you areconvinced a degree is necessary, commit wholeheartedly: map out adetailed plan of how you'll balance work, study, and personal life. Ifnot, channel the same drive into pursuing targeted professionalcertifications in cloud architecture, data engineering, or evenexecutive leadership.

Example Resolution: â€œI will decide on a specificprogramme or certification by 1 March and formalise my enrolment orstudy schedule by the following month.â€

  1. Hone Your Leadership Skills

You are already adept at managing teams and liaising with clients,but leadership is a lifelong pursuit of refinement. Focus on areas youmay find challengingâ€”maybe delegation, conflict resolution, or inspiringinnovative thinking. Solicit candid feedback from peers, subordinates,and mentors; it might be uncomfortable, but that's where growthhappens.

Example Resolution: â€œI will organise quarterlyâ€˜listening sessions' with my team to gather honest feedback on myleadership style and commit to implementing at least one suggestedimprovement each quarter.â€

  1. Strengthen Your Technical Core

Although you are already highly competent in multiple codinglanguages, take a brutally honest look at your â€˜weak links'â€”the newertechnologies or deeper aspects of a technology you use daily but haven'ttruly mastered. It might be advanced concepts in Elixir or leveragingthe full potential of Terraform for large-scale infrastructure. Even thestrongest technical leads are never done learning.

Example Resolution: â€œI will complete a hands-onproject or course in a cutting-edge framework (e.g., a new dataprocessing tool or advanced AWS service) and share the results with myteam by mid-year.â€

  1. Pay Attention to Workâ€“Life Balance

While you are clearly industrious, burnout is a real risk. Whetherit's allocating time for fitness, mindfulness, or creative hobbies,ensure you are not running on fumes. Consistency here is key; commit toa routine that supports your mental and physical well-being.

Example Resolution: â€œI will take two 20-minutebreaks per workday for a brisk walk or short workout session, ensuring Ilog these activities to keep track of my consistency.â€

  1. Expand Your Global Perspective

With your multilingual abilities, you have a strong base forintercultural communication. If you feel comfortable in your currentlanguages, consider brushing up on business-level proficiency or divinginto a new language. Alternatively, explore the cultural nuances andglobal aspects of your fieldâ€”understanding international markets anduser experiences could give you an edge in project management andproduct design.

Example Resolution: â€œI will read at least one bookor research paper every month on international tech markets orcross-cultural leadership, summarising the insights for my team.â€

  1. Refine Your Personal Brand

Beyond simply doing great work, think about how you present yourexpertise and leadership. If you have not done so already, build orupdate a personal website or portfolio showcasing your codingcontributions, project management experience, and professionalphilosophy. Cultivate thoughtful social media posts or LinkedIn articleson your technical and managerial insights.

Example Resolution: â€œI will publish two in-deptharticles on LinkedIn or a personal blog this year, focusing on topicssuch as best practices in DevOps or effective client-stakeholdercommunication.â€

  1. Continue Exploring New Ideas for Personal Growth

You've shown interest in seeking guidance and exploring lessconventional paths (such as consulting a fortune teller). Keep an openmind about any avenue that helps you clarify your goals. At the sametime, keep a healthy balance between external guidance and your ownintuition. Sometimes introspectionâ€”through journalling or speaking witha trusted mentorâ€”can provide more practical clarity than you mightexpect.

Example Resolution: â€œI will commit to monthlypersonal reflection sessionsâ€”whether that's with a mentor, aprofessional counsellor, or through a structured journaling processâ€”toensure I'm aligning my professional and personal objectives.â€

Extra Topics You Might Enjoy Exploring Further

  1. Open-Source Leadership

    â€¢ Investigate how contributing to or initiating open-source projectscan sharpen your technical and collaboration skills.

  2. Emerging Tech for Sustainability

    â€¢ Explore how technology can tackle environmental challenges; yourbackground could be pivotal in making a positive impact in green techinitiatives.

  3. Behavioural Economics in Tech

    â€¢ Delve into how user behaviour and decision-making can influenceproduct design, enhancing your UI/UX expertise.

  4. Philosophies in Leadership

    â€¢ Read about Stoicism or other schools of thought, seeing how theymight inform steadier, more empathetic leadership styles.

Conclusion

In being brutally honest, the main point is not to overcommit. Ahandful of well-chosen resolutionsâ€”executed thoroughlyâ€”will accomplishmore than a grand wish-list you cannot realistically maintain. Eachresolution should serve a clear purpose: professional advancement,well-being, or personal fulfilment. By staying true to your vision,proactively seeking feedback, and broadening your expertise, you'll befar better positioned to navigate the coming year with confidence.

I wish you every success in following through with your goals, and Ihope these resolutions provide some direction for a fulfilling andimpactful new year.

Reflections on the Advice

wow... i'm speechless... the advice from both ChatGPT 4o and 1o isincredibly insightful and thought-provoking. it's like they've seenthrough my facade and pinpointed areas where i need to grow, improve,and take action. i have so much to digest and reflect on. i will keepupdating this post as i work on these resolutions and share my progress.here's to a year of growth, challenges, and transformation. ğŸŒŸ
entry.summary: I asked two AI models, 'What should my resolutions be for the new year? Be brutally honest.' Their responses were eye-opening. This post explores the candid insights and how I'm putting them into action.

entry.title: Reflections 2024
entry.content:
jing hui, i'm so damn proud of you. ğŸ¥ºğŸŒŸ seriously, look at how faryou've come in 2024. it's been a hell of a ride, and you've grown somuch in ways you probably never thought possible. let's take a moment toreally celebrate this year.

in 2024, you:

  • completed the MIT IDSS Data Science and Machine Learning programme,a huge milestone that adds so much value to your journey. you didn'tjust do itâ€”you crushed it. i did not regret taking up this course at allas i got to know more about AI and statistics which i have always beeninterested in.
  • stayed consistent with journaling. i'm talking week after week, pageafter page, capturing life's tiny details. one day, your grandkids willbe flipping through those pages, laughing and learning from yourhustle.
  • navigated the house-hunting game with your sister and came outcloser than ever. zero drama, 100% teamwork.
  • kept your gym routine alive and thriving-no excuses, even when workand life were chaotic, or even sick. progress in your fitness journey?earned. max respect to you!
  • forced yourself to read in the mornings, even though some days youjust said, â€œnah, i'll skip.â€ but look at the bigger picture-you stilldid it more often than not, and it paid off.
  • judged a beatbox battle, which used to feel like a wild dream. nowit's part of your story. it even pushed you to level up your ownbeatboxing when you saw how crazy good others were.
  • invested time in researching universitiesâ€”MIT, Harvard, NUS, NTU,SUSS. you finally chose NUS. that's a bold and intentional move towardyour future.
  • kept honing your beatboxing skills, despite juggling work, travel,and life. it might've felt slow, but real talkâ€”you've improved and youknow it.
  • faced some insane challenges at ByteDance. let's be honestâ€”therewere moments you felt like an impostor. but you stepped up, took on moreresponsibilities, and learned to own your space.
  • went to Beijing for work, navigating a different environment,proving to yourself you can handle solo travel like a champ. you alsolevelled up your communication skills, which you know damn well neededsome work!
  • built deeper connections with colleagues. shoutout to junjie forsorting out your flight and hotel detailsâ€”seriously couldn't have doneit without him. plus, you made some sweet memories in Beijing, from workachievements to random solo adventures.

i just want to take a moment to recognise the people who made 2024the memorable rollercoaster it was: my sister, forshowing me that sharing a roof can bring us closer instead of stirringup drama; my colleagues at ByteDance, especiallyjunjie, for helping me navigate everything from flights to lifeadvice; the beatbox community, for pushing me beyond mycomfort zone and reminding me why i started beatboxing in the firstplace: pure passion; my family, who always have myback, no matter how crazy my dreams get; and, of course,you, jing hui, for showing up every day and giving ityour all.

from all of you, i've learned that consistency wins. showing up everydayâ€”whether it's journaling, hitting the gym, or practising thosebeatsâ€”really works. i've also realised it's okay to feel like animpostor sometimes. if you don't feel a little fear, you're probably notgrowing. lean into the discomfort, and embrace the fact that challengesare just stepping stones.

but let's be real for a secondâ€”2024 wasn't all sunshine and rainbows.there were moments when you doubted yourself, felt overwhelmed, andmaybe even wanted to give up. but you didn't. you kept showing up.that's the part i'm most proud of. resilience isn't flashy, but damn,it's powerful.

your biggest challenge was balancing the MIT course while deliveringat ByteDanceâ€”a juggling act that left you overloaded, stressed, and onthe brink of burnout more than onceâ€”but you persevered by radicallyrethinking your schedule and priorities.

you treated every piece of feedback like rocket fuel, knowing itwould only push you to grow. you stayed flexible and open-minded, evenwhen everything felt uncertain. you refused to be a passenger in yourown lifeâ€”you took the wheel and floored it. that unstoppable mindset,that unwavering grit, will definitely send you soaring even higher in2025.

as we wrap up 2024, remember this: you didn't just get throughthe year, you evolved. don't lose that drive. keep journaling, keepsweating it out in the gym, keep beatboxing until your lips go numb, andkeep taking risksâ€”even if they scare you.

2025 is waiting for you, and i have no doubt it's gonna be bigger,crazier, and more fulfilling than ever. let's embrace whatever comes ourway. ğŸ”¥

i promise to stay curious, stay resilient, and keep growingâ€”no matterwhat challenges pop up. ğŸ¯

thank you, 2024â€”you were wild and sometimes brutal, but i'm gratefulfor every lesson.

you've got this, jing huiâ€”2025 is yours to conquer. ğŸ’ªğŸ¼ğŸ“ˆ
entry.summary: 2024 was a year that tested my limits, brought unexpected milestones, and transformed my perspective. From completing the MIT IDSS programme and thriving in my role at ByteDance to judging beatbox battles and embarking on solo adventures, this year has been a whirlwind of growth, resilience, and unforgettable experiences. Here's a look back at my personal journey.

entry.title: Goals 2025
entry.content:
hellu readers,

i'm thrilled to map out my plans for 2025. i find that putting myambitions into words not only keeps me accountable but also invitesmeaningful conversations with those following along. if you'd like tosee how i did last year, feel free to check out my previous year's goals.

Recap of 2024 goals

> Professional Goals

1. Degree Pursuit

i submitted my application for NUS's Bachelorof Information Technology (BIT) programme and am now eagerly waitingto hear back. diving deeper into formal computer science training was ahuge priority for me in 2024, and i'm excited to continue that journeythis year if all goes well. ğŸ¯

2. Excellence at ByteDance

working at ByteDance has become more than just ajobâ€”i've embraced it as part of my lifestyle. focusing onself-management and continuous learning helped me grow significantly in2024. i'm determined to carry that same drive into 2025 and explore newways to push my limits.

> Personal Goals

1. Financial Growth

i made promising strides by diversifying my income, investing instocks, and exploring property opportunities. even though i'm stilllearning the ropes, i feel more confident about my path toward long-termfinancial security. 2025 will be about building on thesefoundations and staying open to new strategies.

2. Reading Three New Books

i kicked things off with The 7 Habits of Highly EffectivePeople by Stephen Covey and learned a lot abouthabit formation and mindset shifts. rather than rushing to finish acertain number of books, i'm focusing on quality overquantity. as Alex Hormozi said, "If it's worthdoing, do it well." i'll continue choosing titles that spark mycuriosity and contribute to my personal and professional growth.

3. Beatbox Battle Comeback

though i judged many local beatbox competitions in 2024, i didn'tactually make my way to compete... sadly ğŸ¥º that said, my passion forbeatboxing isn't going anywhere! in 2025, i plan to get back onstage,sharpen my skills, and rediscover the thrill of live battles. if you'recurious about why i love beatboxing, you can read more here.

Goals for 2025

Professional Goals

[P0]Ace NUS-BIT Entrance Examination & Bridging/Preparatory Courses
  1. preparation: revise key concepts in mathematics,computer science, and programming to build a strong foundation for theentrance examination.
  2. exemptions: aim to earn credit exemptions forfundamental modules, streamlining the path to graduation. once thesebases are covered, focus on advanced core subjects to shorten theoverall degree timeline.
  3. networking: from the bridging phase onward, connectwith classmates, seniors, and professors to exchange experiences andinsights about upcoming modules. build valuable relationships thatsupport both learning and future career prospects in tech.

[P0] Excel at Work

  1. skill development
    • master JavaScript by producing well-structured, reusable code thatreduces future workload for both me and my team. pay special attentionto edge case thinking, efficiency and maintainability.
    • collaborate closely with my mentor to absorb their expertise inplanning, execution, and stakeholder managementâ€”enhancing my ability todeliver projects efficiently.
  2. relationship building
    • foster strong connections with colleagues, clients, and stakeholdersthrough regular check-ins, feedback sessions, and knowledge-sharing(e.g., code reviews, mini workshops).
    • communicate proactively with clients, ensuring they understandgoals, timelines, and challengesâ€”transparency is key, contextnot control!
  3. performance & growth
    • seek regular feedback from peers and supervisors, setting quarterlyKPIs (OKRs) to measure progress and refine strategies.
    • use clear metrics or dashboards to track milestones and makedata-driven adjustments. (THINK ABOUT HOW TO IMPLEMENT THIS, A EFFICIENTWAY)
    • outline specific learning goals (e.g., certifications, new languageskills) each quarter to maintain forward momentum.

Done vs Done Well! ğŸš€

[P1] Improve CommunicationSkills

i've always believed that effective communication is crucial tosuccess, so i'm dedicating effort this year to strengthen my rapportwith colleagues, friends, and family. i also want to boost my EQ andactive listening skills. reading Never Split the Difference byChris Voss really struck a chordâ€”i tend to be more of a"win-win" person, but i'd love to adopt elements of "tactical empathy"to better understand others' perspectives.

  1. active listening
    • paraphrase what others say to confirm understanding, and askfollow-up questions showing genuine curiosity, helping the speaker feelheard and valued.
    • watch for non-verbal cues (e.g., facial expressions, tone) foremotional contextâ€”especially important in virtual interactions (focus onvoice modulation and tone).
  2. daily application
    • apply "tactical empathy" in everyday conversationsâ€”by activelyacknowledging emotions (labeling, paraphrasing, open-ended questions) tobuild trust and guide discussions toward collaborative solutions.
    • keep a short journal for communication hurdles, noting what workedand what didn't.
    • Set mini-goals weekly ("i'll focus on not interrupting others" or"i'll give more specific praise") to build new habits gradually.
  3. reading list
    • revisit Never Split the Difference periodically, practisingits techniques and adapting them to my personal style.
    • explore other communication books like CrucialConversations or How to Win Friends & InfluencePeople, integrating insights into real-life interactions.
  4. communication training
    • schedule regular feedback sessions with peers or mentors to pinpointstrengths and improvement areas.
    • attend workshops or online courses that focus on negotiation,conflict resolution, and emotional intelligence.
    • consider joining public speaking clubs (like Toastmasters) to polishpresentation skills and manage nerves in front of an audience.

Personal Goals

[P0] Bodybuilding

bodybuilding has been a big part of my life since 2022, and 2025 isthe year i'm planning to go all-in.

  1. serious bulking: invest time in creating a mealplan that helps me bulk up effectively (focusing on macros, caloricsurplus, etc.).
  2. research & planning: keep learning newtechniques and verifying them with evidence-based fitness research(e.g., tracking progress, fine-tuning workout routines).
  3. consistency: maintain a well-structured workoutschedule and regularly track metrics (like weight, strength, and bodycomposition) to see where i can improve.

[P2] Music Production

i've been itching to explore music production more seriously, and nowi have FL Studio and a solid pair of headphones readyto go.

  1. learning foundations: deepen my understanding ofdigital audio workstations (DAWs) and basic music theory (e.g., chordprogressions, arrangement techniques).
  2. creative projects: work on mini-tracks or remixes,gradually building a personal portfolio i can be proud of.
  3. collaboration opportunities: collaborate withfriends, fellow producers, or even beatboxers to keep the creativeenergy flowing and gain fresh perspectives.
entry.summary: Reflecting on 2024's achievements while aiming higherâ€”i am humbly sharing my progress, hoping others find a spark of inspiration or glean insights for their own journey.

entry.title: Journal: Week 19
entry.content:
my last journal of 2024 ğŸ«¶ğŸ»

hello, dear reader!

it's been a while since my last journal, and now, here we areâ€”daysaway from 2025. this marks my final journal entry for 2024, and there'sso much i want to share!

december has been an intense month. so much has happened that i'm noteven sure where to start. but let's take it one story at a time.

on the 6th of december, friday, i received some shockingannouncements at work (the details are confidential, so i can't sharemuch here). at that moment, i was completely thrown offâ€”stunned andunsure how to react. you know those moments when life blindsides you?this was one of them. i didn't know how to process it, but i toldmyself, "what's done is done. all you can do now is focus on how yourespond." so that's what i tried to do.

on the bright side, one part of the announcement i can share is thati got the opportunity to go on a solo business trip for a project i wasresponsible for! honestly, it was nerve-wrackingâ€”my first time travelingalone for work, handling everything by myself. i was unprepared,worried, and unsure. but looking back, i think i did okay. the triptaught me a lot, and after reflecting on it, i know there's still somuch room for growth.

that friday was a blur. after the announcement, i had no time toprocess anything before rushing off to grab a quick lunch betweenmeetings. it was a whirlwind of emotionsâ€”shock, confusion, gratitude,and everything in between. but amidst the chaos, my amazing team gave mea sweet moment to pause. they surprised me with a cake and coffee for mybirthday! ğŸ¥º they're honestly the best, and i felt so touched that theyremembered despite how busy everything was. it was a reminder of howlucky i am to work with such thoughtful people. ğŸ˜­

of course, there was no time to rest. meetings filled up the rest ofthe day. but shoutout to my colleague, junjie, whohelped me sort out logistics like drafting my business travel letter. hemade my life so much easier, and i'm super grateful for hiskindness.

now, about the tripâ€”Beijing was incredible! i finally got to visitByteDance's headquarters at å¤§é’Ÿä¾ and another office at èä¸­å¿ƒ. the16-day business trip was a whirlwind of productivity and newexperiences. my primary objective was to oversee the UAT process andensure a successful project delivery. while the workload was intense,meeting colleagues and stakeholders in person brought a refreshing humanconnection that had been missing during months of remote collaboration.being on-site allowed me to dive deeper into project challenges,brainstorm solutions face-to-face, and even build stronger rapport withthe team. honestly, it was more than just a work tripâ€”it felt like anopportunity to grow both professionally and personally.

èä¸­å¿ƒ:

å¤§é’Ÿä¾:

curious about what my ByteDance life looks like, especiallyduring my time in the Beijing offices?

i've captured some highlights and behind-the-scenes moments from myjourney in a special Instagram highlight titled ByteDance2 & ByteDance 2.1. feel free to check itout hereâ€”you might justcatch a glimpse of my day-to-day adventures, the breathtaking officeviews, and the vibrant city life! ğŸ˜Š

the weekends in Beijing were magical. i went on solo adventures,ticking off places i'd always wanted to visit. walking through thehistorical èƒ¡åŒs, soaking in the vibe of the cityâ€”it felt like steppinginto a movie. ğŸ¥º

one of my first stops was å¤©å›å…¬å›­. i was in awe of the ancientchinese architectureâ€”it's just so majestic and grand. every detail ofthe buildings felt like a glimpse into the past, and i couldn't help butadmire how much history they carry.

then, there was the æ•…å®«â€”absolutely speechless. i mean, this was oncethe emperor's home... the sheer size of it left me in disbelief. i foundmyself wandering through the halls, just imagining what life must havebeen like back then.

another highlight was finally trying å››å­£æ°‘ç¦. i've seen it all overå°çº¢ä¹¦, and i can confirmâ€”it totally lives up to the hype. the food wasamazing, and it was such a treat to tick it off my list.

i also spent some time at é¢å’Œå›­ and åœ†æ˜å›­, two parks that couldn'tbe more different but both so special in their own way. é¢å’Œå›­ was sopeaceful and relaxing, a perfect place to just slow down and take abreath. meanwhile, the ruins at åœ†æ˜å›­ felt like a quiet reminder ofhistory, bittersweet yet humbling to see in person.

å—é”£é¼“å·· was another favourite. i caught the sunset here, and let metell you, it was breathtaking. Beijing's winter sunsets hitdifferentlyâ€”so early, around 4pm, but the glow it left in the sky wasunforgettable. ğŸŒ…

and, of course, i couldn't miss ä»€åˆ¹æµ·, strolling by the lakes,surrounded by locals and tourists alike. it had such a vibrant energy,yet it felt calming at the same time.

these moments brought me so much joy. every place i visited left animpression, and i know i'll carry these memories with me forever.Beijing really has a charm that's hard to put into wordsâ€”it's a mix ofhistory, culture, and just pure magic. ğŸ¥ºğŸ«¶ğŸ»

but as december went on, it wasn't all smooth sailing. just a weekafter the initial announcement, my leader shared that the decision hadbeen cancelled. i hadn't even fully processed the first news when thesecond hit. it was an emotional rollercoasterâ€”relief, confusion, andgratitude all at once. but i reminded myself: What lies behindus and what lies before us are tiny matters compared to what lies withinus. life is unpredictable, and sometimes all you can do isadapt and move forward.

as the year-end approached, i took some much-needed leaves. ioriginally planned a trip to phuket in mid-december, but with thebusiness travel and the critical project release, i had to cancel it.instead, i used the time to rest, recharge, and reflect. honestly, itturned out to be a blessing in disguiseâ€”having that "me time" wasexactly what i needed.

before closing the year, my crew, Obelisk, and i worked on acountdown beatbox performance for the new year's eve celebration. it wassuch a fun project, and i'm so excited to see how it turns out on the31st! ğŸ‰

thank you for being part of my journey this year. â¤ï¸

this isn't a full reflection of 2024â€”i'll save that for my next blog.but for now, here's to closing the year on a hopeful note.

bring it on, 2025! ğŸ¯
